TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: clayey, smectitic, acid, thermic, shallow Xerertic Torriorthents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Morenogulch paragravelly silty clay, on a west facing convex slope of 78 percent under soft chess, foxtail fescue, and buckwheat at 1040 feet elevation.  (Colors are for dry soils unless otherwise stated.  When described on November 18, 1987, the soil was moist throughout.)
A1--0 to 3 inches; pinkish gray (7.5YR 6/2) paragravelly silty clay, brown (7.5YR 4/2) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure parting to weak fine subangular blocky and moderate fine granular; loose, slightly hard, very friable, moderately sticky and moderately plastic; many very fine and fine roots; many very fine and fine interstitial pores; 25 percent 2 to 8 millimeters shale fragments; 4 percent 1 to 3 centimeters gypsum crystals; strongly acid (pH 5.4); clear smooth boundary.  (1 to 3 inches thick)
A2--3 to 6 inches; pinkish gray (7.5YR 6/2) very paragravelly silty clay, brown (7.5YR 4/2) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, moderately sticky and moderately plastic; many very fine and fine and few medium roots; many very fine and fine interstitial pores; 40 percent 2 to 10 millimeters shale fragments; 8 percent 3 to 40 millimeters gypsum crystals in the soil matrix; strongly acid (pH 5.2); clear wavy boundary.  (1 to 3 inches thick)
Cy--6 to 10 inches; pinkish gray (7.5YR 6/2) extremely paragravelly silty clay, brown (7.5YR 4/2) moist; massive; friable, moderately sticky and moderately plastic; common very fine and fine roots concentrated near the top of the horizon; many very fine and fine interstitial pores; 65 percent 2 to 20 millimeters shale fragments; 4 percent 3 to 20 millimeters gypsum crystals in the soil matrix; extremely acid (pH 4.4); gradual wavy boundary. (3 to 4 inches thick)
Cr1--10 to 15 inches; pinkish gray (7.5YR 6/2), brownish yellow (10YR 6/6), and reddish brown (2.5YR 5/4) mudstone shale; 50 percent brown (7.5YR 4/2), 35 percent yellowish brown (10YR 5/6), and 15 percent reddish brown (2.5YR 4/4) moist; few very fine and fine roots; few fine filaments and seams of gypsum occur between shale layers; extremely acid (pH 4.2); gradual wavy boundary.  (3 to 5 inches thick)
Cr2--15 to 26 inches; pinkish gray (7.5YR 6/2), brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) and reddish brown (2.5YR 5/4) mudstone shale with (two) 2 cm thick bands of white (N 8/0) diatomaceous rock; 70 percent brown (7.5YR 4/2), 10 percent yellowish brown (10YR 5/6), 10 percent reddish brown (2.5YR 4/4), and 10 percent white (N 8/0) moist; few very fine and fine roots; very few filaments and seams and 1 cm thick 30 to 90 cm long channels of gypsum oriented on shale layers; common sulfur deposits on upper side of gypsum fragments; extremely acid (pH 4.1); gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 11 inches thick)
Cr3--26 to 33 inches; brown (7.5YR 4/2) and yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) mudstone shale; 80 percent brown (7.5YR 4/2) and 20 percent yellowish brown (10YR 5/6); very few very fine roots; very few filaments and seams and 1 cm thick 30 to 90 cm long channels of gypsum oriented on shale layers; extremely acid (pH 4.1).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Fresno County, California; approximately 200 feet west of Panoche Mountain Road; about 3,740 feet east and 225 feet south of the northwest corner of section 3, T. 14S, R. 11E, MDB&M; Latitude 36 degrees, 44 minutes, 54 seconds north; Longitude 120 degrees, 45 minutes, 40 seconds; USGS Mercey Hot Springs Quadrangle.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS: The mean annual soil temperature is 64 to 66 degrees F.  The thickness of the ochric epipedon ranges from 2 to 6 inches.  Organic carbon content ranges from 0.50 to 1.90 percent in the ochric epipedon, and it decreases regularly to less than 0.50 percent below a depth of 6 inches.  The particle size control section ranges from 35 to 55 percent clay.   Electrical conductivity ranges from 0.4 to 3.6 decisiemens per meter.  Selenium content ranges from 4 to 13 parts per million.  Gypsum content ranges from 1 to 18 percent.  Depth to diatomaceous rock is 6 to 15 inches.
The A horizon colors are 7/5YR 6/2, 6/3; 10YR 5/2, 5/3, or 6/3.  Moist colors are 7.5Y 4/2, 4/3; 10YR 3/2, 4/3, 5/2, or 5/3.  Texture is paragravelly or very paragravelly clay, silty clay, or silty clay loam.  The reaction is very strongly acid or strongly acid (pH 4.5 to 5.5).
The Cy horizon colors are 7/5YR 6/2, 6/3; 10YR 5/2, 5/3, 6/3, or 6/4.  Moist colors are 7.5Y 4/2, 4/3; 10YR 4/3, 5/3, or 5/4.  Texture is very paragravelly or extremely paragravelly clay, silty clay, or silty clay loam.  The reaction is extremely acid or very strongly acid (pH 3.5 to 5.0).
The Cr horizon reaction is extremely acid or very strongly acid (pH 3.5 to 5.0).

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: There are no other competing series in this family.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING: Morenogulch soils are on backslopes of hills and mountains and have slopes of 50 to 80 percent.  Elevations range from 550 to 3130 feet.  The soils have formed in material weathered from mudstone, shale, and diatomaceous rock with intermixed gypsum crystals of the Moreno formation.  The climate is semiarid with hot dry summers and cool moist winters.  The mean annual precipitation is 8 to 12 inches.  Mean January temperature is 46 degrees F; mean July temperature is 81 degrees F; mean annual temperature is 62 degrees F.  The frost free season is 220 to 245 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the Belgarra(T) and Exclose(T) soils.  Belgarra and Exclose soils are deep and very deep respectively.  Belgarra and Exclose soils are in general considerably more alkaline that the Morenogulch soils.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY: Somewhat excessively drained, very rapid runoff, slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: These soils are mainly used as wildlife habitat.  The vegetation is sparse and consists primarily of desert trumpet, with some areas of buckwheat, soft chess, and foxtail.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: These soils are found in the Coastal Mountain Ranges of California.  They are not extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  These soils were previously mapped as Badland.  They are considered a major source of selenium to certain alluvial fans in the Central Valley of California.
ADDITIONAL DATA:  NSSL lab data is available for the Typical Pedon from soil sample S87CA-019-017 (88P1507-88P1512).  Additional lab data is available in soil samples 85T7575, 85T7576, 87P1208, 87P1201, 87P1202, 87P1203.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
